node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Science & Astronomy on August 04, 2021. May be an image of sky.

node.text: Based on our current understanding of physics, the universe technically shouldn’t exist. Current models predict that when the universe was born in the Big Bang, there should have been equal amounts of matter and antimatter. However, given that the observable universe is composed only of regular matter and not antimatter, obviously there was some discrepancy early on. When matter and antimatter meet, the two will quickly cancel each other out, destroying themselves in a burst of energy. Since current models of physics predict that the early universe should have had equal amounts of both, matter itself should not exist, yet obviously it does. Our current understanding of physics is unable to explain this problem, which strongly suggests that physics is in dire need of an update. It’s possible that the universe is the product of some event that occurred prior to the Big Bang, an event that broke the symmetry of the early universe and caused a significant difference in the amount of matter and antimatter. It’s also possible that different laws apply to antimatter than regular matter, yet this seems somewhat unlikely given that experiments using antimatter have been unable to detect any new laws of physics being applied. As of yet, the very existence of matter is a mystery. But after all, who doesn’t like a good mystery? Especially when it has to do with the existence of, well, everything we can see. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nasa #esa #hubble #telescope #nature

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Science & Astronomy on July 26, 2021. May be a closeup of nature.

node.text: At first glance, you may think the image above is of our moon, yet it is in fact an up close view of the largest moon in the solar system, Ganymede. This stunning image was taken by NASA’s Juno spacecraft in June. It may seem surprising that Ganymede looks very similar to our moon, yet it actually makes sense. Both our moon and Ganymede lack any kind of geologic activity, and so any impact craters on the surface will last for billions of years. However, despite appearances, Ganymede is a lot different than our moon. Ganymede is over 2,600 km across, making it larger than even Mercury and over 900 km larger than our moon. Even the craters on Ganymede are distinct from those on our moon. The craters on Ganymede have virtually no vertical relief, making them relatively flat. Other surface features that cannot be found on our moon are long grooves that stretch across Ganymede’s surface, some of which can reach up to 700 meters high. How these grooves formed is somewhat of a mystery, yet they may be the result of some form of geologic activity as there are very few craters located along these grooves. It’s possible that fault lines formed along these grooves as water underneath the surface escaped into space. These images are currently the closest images we have of Ganymede, so we may know a lot more about this gigantic moon in the near future. Image credit: NASA, Juno #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nature #nasa #telescope #space

node.text: One of the first laws of nature that we become familiar with is the conservation of energy. It’s a simple law, yet it also has profound implications for the universe. In its essence, the conservation of energy claims that energy can neither be created or destroyed, that the total amount of stuff going into a system will be the same amount of stuff coming out. Energy can change, but it’s never destroyed. Interestingly, this simple law means that the total amount of stuff in the universe has always remained constant. The amount of energy present in the Big Bang is still present in the universe today. Energy changes form, but it never vanishes. This means that the very atoms born in the aftermath of the Big Bang went on to form every piece of matter we see in the universe, including every atom in our bodies. Hydrogen was the first atom to form in the aftermath of the Big Bang, along with small amounts of helium and lithium. Even today, hydrogen still makes up the majority of the universe’s visible matter. Since hydrogen came first, it follows that every other element formed from hydrogen, with the stars themselves fusing hydrogen into heavier elements, eventually going supernova and dispersing their newly formed atoms into the cosmos. Those heavy elements then go on to form a new generation of stars and planets, including our own. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nature #nasa #esa #hubble #telescope

node.text: Here on Earth, the fastest winds ever recorded reached 408 km/h during a tropical cyclone in Australia in 1996. Although that seems extremely fast, it’s nothing compared to the fastest winds ever recorded in the solar system. Neptune is home to the fastest winds in the solar system, moving at about 2,000 km/h. If winds of this speed occurred on Earth, they would move faster than the speed of sound. However, since the speed of sound is dependent on the density of the air, they do not exceed the speed of sound on Neptune. Here on Earth, our weather is a direct result of our planet’s absorption of solar radiation. The heat from the sun supplies the energy produced in large storms, yet given that Neptune is located a staggering 4.5 billion km away from the sun, how does it manage to produce winds of such magnitude? Interestingly, prior to the Voyager 2 flyby of Neptune, scientists had assumed that Neptune’s atmosphere would be featureless due to the lack of solar radiation. Furthermore, the atmosphere of Uranus was largely featureless, and it orbits the sun 1.5 billion km closer than Neptune. When Voyager 2 gathered data on Neptune’s temperature, astronomers were stunned to find that Neptune’s temperatures aren’t that different from Uranus. Exactly why Neptune is so warm is still a mystery, especially when we consider the fact that we haven’t gone back to Neptune since the Voyager 2 flyby in 1989. Most of what we know about Neptune came from that flyby. Here’s something interesting to think about. Both Jupiter and Saturn have been visited since the Voyager flybys, and the amount of information we gained during consecutive missions really shows just how little data you can gather during a single flyby. The amount we know about Uranus and Neptune currently is almost equivalent to what we knew about Jupiter and Saturn 40 years ago. Even in our own solar system, there is still a lot we do not know about the outer planets. In Neptune’s case, the reason behind its high internal temperatures and fast winds are a mystery. (Post continues in the comments ⬇️⬇️⬇️)

node.text: Humans occupy a minuscule amount of time relative to the age of the Earth. The best available evidence places the first modern humans around 200,000 years ago. Relative to the Earth, which is about 4.5 billion years old, our species has occupied only 0.0044% of the Earth’s history. For over 99% of the Earth’s history, there were no humans. Now consider the fact that humans have really only possessed what we can call “advanced” technology for about one hundred to two hundred years. For the vast majority of our own existence, we were simply hunters and gatherers. Given this information, what will our species leave behind that could one day be found as evidence for our existence? Will we leave anything behind that would suggest a technologically advanced civilization once occupied a sliver of time in Earth’s history? Even our oldest structures, such as the Great Pyramid, will erode away and turn to dust, leaving no evidence of their existence. Human fossils would perhaps hint at some form of intelligence, yet it wouldn’t offer any insight into our civilization. All of our cities will one day disappear and return to the Earth, leaving no trace of their existence. Interestingly, one of the only forms of evidence that our civilization once existed will be in the form of plastic. Given how plastic is extremely difficult for natural processes to break down, humans will likely leave a marker in the geologic record, a layer of plastic. Yet even this layer of plastic would be extraordinarily thin, especially given that we haven’t even been using plastic for a hundred years. Given its widespread use and abundance, however, humans will leave behind a marker in the Earth’s rocks. And plastic isn’t the only marker. Nuclear tests that occurred over the course of the Cold War have left radioactive markers in the rocks, and our greenhouse gas emissions will also likely leave a mark in the rocks. If we one day go extinct, and another civilization evolves in the far future, perhaps they will identify a pattern. (Post continues in the comments ⬇️⬇️⬇️)

node.text: In the late 1500s, the astronomer Johannes Kepler observed a large gap located between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. He concluded that a planet must exist in this region, as it was too large to simply contain nothing. This idea, that another planet existed, held sway for quite some time. Astronomers had just largely assumed that this large gap was simply the orbital path of an undiscovered planet. Then in 1801, astronomer Giuseppe Piazzi discovered a small object orbiting within this gap. It was named Ceres, and many astronomers believed they had found the missing planet. However, further observations revealed that Ceres was remarkably small. No matter what telescope they used, Ceres remained as nothing more than a small point of light, almost indistinguishable from the background stars. Over the next couple years, more tiny objects like Ceres were discovered in this gap. Although they were all designated as planets, the astronomer William Herschel had a different idea. In 1802, he concluded that these objects were not planets at all, but rather, should be placed in their own category of celestial objects. He called this new category “asteroids”, after the Greek word for “star-like”. However, even though Herschel had made this conclusion, astronomers still continued to classify these small objects as planets. As the years went on, more and more of these objects were found in between Mars and Jupiter. By the 1850s, astronomers began to conclude that these were not planets, but were in fact asteroids. The seemingly empty region in between Mars and Jupiter was in fact home to countless asteroids, and it became known as the Asteroid Belt. To this day, there is still some mystery surrounding the Asteroid Belt. Its existence had originally been thought to be the result of a planet that had existed yet broke apart, yet this was disproven when astronomers calculated the total mass of all the asteroids and found it was nowhere near enough to make an entire planet. (Post continues in the comments ⬇️⬇️⬇️)

node.text: The majority of the stars in our galaxy exist in groups of two or more. Star clusters are massive congregations of stars, and they are truly stunning. Star clusters come in two general types: open clusters and globular clusters. Interestingly, the two are basically opposites of each other. Open clusters generally contain hundreds to thousands of stars, most of which are young and massive. Perhaps the most popular example of an open cluster is the Pleiades. The Pleiades is one of the only star clusters that’s visible to the naked eye, and it’s also one of the closest at 444 light years away. As an open cluster, the Pleiades contains an abundance of high mass blue stars, most of which having formed in just the last 500 million years. There are two main factors that explain why open clusters tend to be young. First is the fact that high mass stars have relatively short lifespans. Their high internal temperatures burn through their supply of hydrogen within a few hundred million years. Second is the fact that the distances between stars in an open cluster is simply too large to keep them together forever. Eventually, the stars slowly move away from each other and the cluster ceases to exist. As for globular clusters, pretty much all of their characteristics are the opposite of open clusters. They generally contain millions of stars, the majority of which are low mass red stars. Since the majority of a globular cluster’s stars are low mass stars, their lifespan extends for many billions of years. Hence most globular clusters are very old, some as old as the Milky Way itself. Furthermore, since most stars are located so close to one another, their mutual gravity keeps the cluster intact for billions of years. It’s interesting to think about what it would be like to stand on the surface of a planet located within a globular cluster. During both day and night, your sky would be lit by the combined light of millions of stars. The first five images show globular clusters, while the second half show open clusters. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #space #nature #nasa #esa #hubble #telescope

node.text: Why do objects have mass? Mass is a concept that we generally take for granted. We all know what it is, yet why does it exist at all? Why, for example, does an electron have mass yet a photon does not? Most particles have mass because of the interaction of the kinetic energy contained within things like quarks and gluons. For some particles, however, their mass is derived from their interaction with what’s known as the Higgs field. Basically, the Higgs field is a field of potential energy that permeates all of space. Some particles interact with this field, with the potential energy of the Higgs field transferring to those particles and giving them mass. Here’s a simple example to help you grasp what this means. Imagine trying to walk through a field of mud. Obviously trying to walk through mud is going to be difficult as the viscosity causes drag. The Higgs field is like that mud, causing drag on particles and giving them mass. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nature #nasa #esa #hubble #telescope

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Science & Astronomy on July 13, 2021.

node.text: Isaac Newton’s law of gravity is perhaps one of the greatest intellectual achievements of humankind. Newton showed that if you knew all the initial conditions of some event, you could accurately deduce what will happen in the future. Newton’s work started what we now call classical physics. Although the predictive power of Newton’s work is astonishing, it wasn’t the complete story. Despite the success of his law of gravity, even Newton understood it was far from complete. Newton was unable to define what exactly gravity is. It’s a force that objects of mass exert on one another, yet Newton could not describe what that “force” actually was. It took another genius by the name of Albert Einstein to figure it out. Newton had earlier defined space as being absolute. To Newton, space was an unchanging landscape that events occur in. Einstein, however, thought differently. Einstein believed that space was not absolute. Rather, Einstein suggested that space was dynamic. Space could be warped, stretched, compressed, etc. This led to another breakthrough by Einstein. Gravity, as it turns out, is simply the effect of the warping of space. Objects with mass can warp the fabric of space around them, almost creating a kind of “indent” in space. The force of gravity is the effect of this warping. The sun, for example, warps the space around it, while all the planets travel along the curvature of space that the sun has produced. The force of gravity is the physical effect of space pushing you down. Einstein had finally defined what gravity was, and although we still use Newton’s math to this day, Einstein’s theories of relativity led us into a new age of physics. Classical physics, although still extremely useful, was unable to explain events that occur under extreme conditions, such as extreme masses or speeds. Einstein solved this issue. Using his theories of relativity, scientists could now understand what happens when you travel at the speed of light or what happens when you approach a black hole. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nasa #hubble #telescope #esa #nature

node.text: The sun is the most powerful object in our solar system. As the strongest gravitational influence in the solar system, it holds all eight planets and countless other objects in its orbit. Despite it being 150 million kilometres away from our world, we can still feel its energy when we step outside. Occasionally, if you’re lucky enough to see them, the sun’s energy produces a dazzling display of lights called the aurora. They are generally only visible near Earth’s poles, yet on rare occasions they can be visible at different latitudes. What I’ve always found fascinating about the aurora is that the story of their formation begins with the sun. Solar radiation interacts with our atmosphere and ionizes the gases in our upper atmosphere. The reason why they occur mostly at the poles is because our magnetic field directs the solar wind towards the poles. Here it interacts with the molecules within our atmosphere, stripping them of their electrons and producing a magnificent display of bright, neon lights. Image credit: Solar Dynamics Observatory, International Space Station #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nature #nasa #hubble #telescope

node.text: Science is by far the most powerful tool we humans have ever developed. In the last hundred years, we’ve advanced more technologically and scientifically than perhaps the rest of human history combined. Despite the pace at which we advance, we don’t often take note to the fact that science is constantly occurring in real time. Perhaps the reason for this is that most of it seems irrelevant to our daily lives. However, during the COVID-19 pandemic, we got to witness science occur in real time in a way that was relevant to our daily lives. That’s why information was changing on a near daily basis. Science is a never ending process of discovery, of gathering data and evidence to understand the natural world. Since more data and better evidence can always be gathered, the information we heard a year ago may be far different than the information we receive now. It’s not that science is flawed, it’s just a product of having a tool that is constantly gathering more information. The only thing that can be used to dispel science is better science. Over time science corrects itself. That’s the whole point of the process. We understand that what we know is a drop of water in an ocean of mystery. Science will always change as we advance technologically and discover new ways of gathering data and interpreting evidence. So much of nature is still a mystery, and the only way we’ll ever hope of dispelling that mystery is through science. Image credit: NASA/ESA, Hubble #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nasa #hubble #esa #space #nature

node.text: It may not be considered a planet anymore, but Pluto is still as interesting as the planets that orbit our central star. Up until 2015, Pluto was largely a mystery. We had no clear images of its surface, and so things like it’s geology and past were pure speculation. Then in the summer of 2015, NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft became the first spacecraft to successfully fly through the Pluto system, taking the highest resolution images of its surface to date. New Horizons revealed an absolutely stunning world, one with vast nitrogen ice plains, mountains made of ice, canyons, and evidence of past volcanism. There’s even some evidence that liquid nitrogen flows on the surface. So why is a world so interesting not considered to be a planet anymore? In 2006, astronomers classified Pluto as a dwarf planet, and to this day, people still debate whether or not that was a good decision. Changing the classification of a world says nothing about what that world is like, and so regardless of what we think Pluto is, it’s still an interesting world worth visiting again in the future. The reasons behind the 2006 decision have to do with other worlds that were discovered in the solar system. In 2005, astronomers discovered another small world called Eris, also located in the Kuiper Belt. Astronomers classified Eris as a dwarf planet, yet it was actually more massive than Pluto. Eris ignited a debate on whether or not these small worlds should be considered planets, or if they should all be classified as dwarf planets. Then in 2006, astronomers devised a definition of what a planet is. In order to be a planet, a world must fit three criteria. First, it must orbit the sun. Second, it must have a strong enough gravitational pull so as to become spherical in shape. Third, it must have a strong enough gravitational pull to clear its orbital path of debris. Although Pluto meets the first two criteria, it does not meet the last one. Unfortunately, Pluto’s gravity is too weak to clear its orbital path of debris, and so Pluto was downgraded to dwarf planet. Image credit: NASA, New Horizons #science #physics #astronomy #astrophysics #nasa #space #nature
